awd_titl_txt: Conference: Workshop/Exploring National Infrastructure for Public Access Usage and Impact Reporting
awd_abstract_narration:
This targeted convening of experts on open science and public access will bring together specific leading cyberinfrastructure experts to: a) explore approaches to producing cross-platform public and open impact analytics at scale, b) discuss open infrastructure opportunities to improve the FAIRness of usage data, and c) identify needed steps to scaffold America’s national infrastructure for scholarly output impact reporting in light of the Nelson memo and the European Open Science Cloud Core and Interoperability Framework.  Workshop findings will be documented in a report that will be distributed through public repositories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Usage data on research outputs such as books and journals is well established in the scholarly community. However, as research impact is derived from a broader set of scholarly outputs, such as data, code and multimedia, more holistic usage and impact metrics could inform national innovation and research policy. Usage data reporting standards, such as Project COUNTER, provide the basis for shared statistics reporting practice; however, as mandated access to publicly funded research has increased the demand for impact metrics and analytics, stakeholders are exploring how to scaffold and strengthen shared infrastructure to better support the trusted, multi-stakeholder exchange of usage data across a variety of outputs.

Conference support from NSF brought together twenty in-person subject matter experts and six remote speakers to identify challenges to US-based cross-platform scholarship impact analytics at scale. The workshop was held in Denver, CO, in April 2023. Specifically, participants explored open infrastructure and research opportunities to improve the FAIRness of usage data, and identify opportunities to scaffold America’s national infrastructure for scholarly output impact reporting in light of the Nelson memo and the European Open Science Cloud Core and Interoperability Framework.

Challenges to public access impact reporting for data, articles, books, and special digital collections was explored. Participant generated recommendations addressed alignment with trans-national scholarly infrastructure efforts and areas for future domestic research and infrastructure development. Workshop findings were documented and distributed through public repositories. 

This workshop increased knowledge exchange while fostering relationship building across executive leaders of publishers, repositories, scholarly infrastructures, and funding agencies. It increased awareness of activities underway in Europe and perspectives among public and private funding organizations. Research outputs documented an archival snapshot of the state of publicly usage and impact data exchange and analytics.

Four key areas for action were identified that will strengthen infrastructure for impact metrics for publicly accessible scholarship: 1) engaging further stakeholders working with other output types and internationally, 2) piloting a Minimum Viable Product for a usage data trust, 3) understanding and committing to shared values and principles and 4) addressing and clarifying usage data ownership.
